metadata.title: The construction of electrochemical aptasensor based on coral-like poly-aniline and Au nano-particles for the sensitive detection of prostate specific antigen

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Sensors and Actuators B: Chemical
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/snb
The construction of electrochemical aptasensor based on coral-like polyaniline and Au nano-particles for the sensitive detection of prostate specific antigen
Zhenjiang Lia, Jifang Yinb, Chenghai Gaob, Guanhao Qiua, Alan Mengc,⁎, Qingdang Lia
a Key Laboratory of Polymer Material Advanced Manufacturing Technology of Shandong Provincial, College of Electromechanical Engineering, College of Sino-German Science and Technology, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, 266061, Shandong, PR China b College of Materials Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, 266042, Shandong, PR China c Key Laboratory of Sensor Analysis of Tumor Marker, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, 266042, Shandong, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Coral-like PANI AuNPs Peptides Prostate specific antigen Aptasensor Electrodeposition
A B S T R A C T
Prostate specific antigen (PSA), as the significant biomarker of prostate cancer, has aroused widespread concern. However, constructing the PSA aptasensor with high sensitivity and low detection limit is still facing huge challenges. In this study, a sensitive electrochemical aptasensor for detecting PSA based on coral-like polyaniline (PANI)/gold nano-particles (AuNPs) and the peptides was constructed. Coral-like PANI and AuNPs with the diameter of 50–80 nm, as the substrate materials, were directly deposited on glass carbon electrode (GCE) by electrodeposited method. Then, the peptides, as the antifouling materials, were anchored on the modifiedelectrode, which not only can form antifouling surface to reduce nonspecific adsorption, but also can be as a medium between the modified-electrode and PSA aptamer. Finally, the PSA aptamer was immobilized on the electrode. Based on the synergistic effect of excellent conductivity and special morphology of the substrate materials, and the antifouling ability of peptides, the aptasensor exhibited a high sensitivity of 462.7 μA(ng mL−1)−1 cm−2, wide linear range from 0.1 pg mL-1 to 100 ng mL-1, low limit of detection (LOD) of 0.085 pg mL-1 and good antifouling performance. The aptasensor also possessed outstanding selectivity, reproducibility and stability. Moreover, the aptasensor can directly detect PSA in 10% human serum solutions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Prostate cancer, as the second leading cause of death among males, is a major global healthy concern [1]. Prostate specific antigen (PSA), as a significant protein signal for prostate cancer, is considered to be the most efficient biomarker for the detection of prostate cancer. The normal concentration of PSA is lower than 4.0 ng mL−1 for healthy men, but when the concentration of PSA is above 10 ng mL−1, it may be suspected that a man have a risk of prostate cancer [2,3]. Moreover, the level of PSA can be used to evaluate the recovery of patients’ undergoing prostatectomy. For postoperative patients, it is considered as viable cancer when the concentration of PSA is up to 0.5 ng mL−1 [4]. Therefore, it is critical to develop sensitive and specific methods for detecting PSA in the early diagnosis of the prostate cancer and monitoring the effectiveness of the treatments.
Recently, a series of methods have been developed for detecting PSA, such as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA),
electrochemiluminescence, fluorescence, chemiluminescence, surface enhanced Raman scattering and electrochemical method [5–10]. Among these methods, electrochemical method with the inherent advantages of quick response, high sensitivity, simple operation, and miniaturization capacity have attracted much interest. For example, Li et al. constructed a sensitive electrochemical immunosensor to detect PSA based on Au nanoparticles and PdPtCu nanospheres [11]. Based on AuNPs/nano-PEDOT-GA nanocomposite, Jia et al. fabricated a highperformance electrochemical platform for PSA detection [12]. Meanwhile, according to the catalytic performance of Au@Pt nanocrystals, Wang et al. constructed an electrochemical aptasensor to detect PSA [13]. However, in the above studies, PSA antibodies were usually selected as recognition probes for PSA detection. Although the antibodies have been used extensively to analyze a series of proteins, its modification process and in-vivo preparation are high-cost and time consuming [14]. The oligonucleotide aptamers, which are usually stable and short single-stranded DNA or RNA sequences, as the alternatives of
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2019.05.070 Received 23 February 2019; Received in revised form 16 May 2019; Accepted 20 May 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: alanmengqust@163.com (A. Meng).
Sensors & Actuators: B. Chemical 295 (2019) 93–100
Available online 21 May 2019 0925-4005/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
the antibodies, gradually attract the interest of researchers. The aptamer detecting PSA is synthesized by Savory and co-worker [15] and it has been used in many researches. For example, based on gold nanospears and PSA aptamer, Rahi et.al constructed a label-free electrochemical aptasensor for detecting human prostate-specific antigen [16]. Souada et al. also used PSA aptamer as the recognition probe to detect PSA with a good performance [17]. Moreover, Heydari-Bafrooei et al. used gold nanoparticles and rGO-MWCNT composite materials to construct electrochemical aptasensor for achieving PSA detection [18]. Because of the inherent affinity and specificity with the targets, the aptamer can specifically identify with the target molecules, and can achieve the same effect as antibodies [19]. Therefore, the PSA aptamer will be a promising alternative in PSA detection.
Moreover, the antifouling ability of the aptasensor for detecting actual samples is also important. Currently, common antifouling materials mainly include PEG-based coatings, protease-based antifouling films, isoporous silica-micelle membrane, zwitterionic materials and so on [20–23]. However, these materials have several disadvantages such as complex preparation process and narrow use range. What’s more, most of them are not commercially available. Nowadays, the peptides are attracting more and more attention because of their simple synthetic process and low cost [24]. In addition, the peptides have alternating carboxyl (−COOH) and amino groups (-NH2), which can strongly bind to water molecules via hydration to improve the hydrophilicity of the surface [25]. The surface with high hydrophilicity can effectively resist the nonspecific adsorption of single and complex proteins on the electrode surface. Therefore, antifouling aptasensor can be constructed based on the peptides.
More importantly, it is reported that excellent substrate materials played a key role in constructing the electrochemical aptasensor in recent years. Currently, common substrate materials are Au/Pt/Ag nanoparticles [26,27], Cu nanocrystals [28], graphene-based composite [29], quantum dots [30] and so on. Although the materials have been used extensively and have good performance, they are often dropped on the electrode surface. For the drip method, the introduction of the adhesive and the weak adhesion between the materials and the electrode will weaken the performance of the aptasensor. But for conducting polymer, it can be directly grown on the electrode by electrodeposition method. By using electrodeposition method, the adhesion strength between the electrode and substrate materials can be enhanced, and the amount and morphology of the materials can be easy to control. Moreover, the conducting polymers, such as PANI, have low power consumption, excellent conductivity, and easy-controllability [31]. Therefore, it is an effective strategy to deposit the conductive polymer on electrode by electrodeposition to construct a sensor. Hao et al. used PANI nanowires as the substrate materials to construct a sensitive electrochemical biosensor for detecting hepatitis B virus gene [32]. Based on Gr and microporous PANI, Sha et al. constructed an electrochemical sensor for non-enzymatic detection of urea [33]. Above all, based on the excellent property of electrodeposition method, PANI and peptides, it can be inferred that the aptasensor with high performance can be constructed.
Herein, a sensitive and antifouling aptasensor towards PSA was constructed (as can be seen in Scheme 1), of which, coral-like PANI and AuNPs as substrate materials were deposited on GCE by electrodeposited method. The peptides (CRERERE) as the antifouling materials were subsequently modified on the substrate materials. Then, the PSA aptamer was immobilized on the peptides. The as-aptasensor exhibited a wide linear range, a low limit of detection (LOD) and high sensitivity. In addition, the as-prepared aptasensor also have outstanding selectivity, admirable reproducibility and satisfying stability. Due to the introduction of the peptides, the aptasensor can detect PSA in 10% human serum solutions. Moreover, the aptasensor also can provide useful reference for the construction of other sensors.

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents and apparatus
sections.text:
PSA was purchased from Shanghai Linc-Bio Science Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). The aptamer DNA of PSA (5′-NH2-TTT TTA ATT AAA GCT CGC CAT CAA ATA GCT TT-3′) was synthesized by SBS Genetech Co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Human serum albumin (HSA), human immunoglobulin G (IgG), bovine serum albumin (BSA), and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) were purchased from Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Aniline was bought from Aladdin Reagents (Shanghai, China). The peptide (sequence: CRERERE, purity> 95%) was ordered from Bank peptide Biological Technology Co., Ltd (Hefei, China). N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) and 1-ethyl-3-3-(dimethy-laminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. All other chemical agents used in the experiment were analytical-reagent grade and without any purification. The solutions of the aptamer, the peptides, and PSA were prepared by using phosphate buffered saline (PBS) (10mM, pH=7.4). All solutions were prepared with Millipore water, which was obtained from a Milli-Q water purifying system.
The morphology of the products was characterized by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, SM-6460LV, Japan). The chemical composition of the samples was analyzed by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250, U.S.A.). Static water contact angle was measured by the JC2000 Instrument (Shanghai Zhongchen Instrument Co., China). All experiments were implemented at room temperature unless otherwise stated.

sections.heading: 2.2. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: All electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co. Ltd., China). A classic three-electrode system was used in the experiment, which was made up of a bare or modified GCE (diameter, 3.0 mm, as the working electrode), a platinum wire (as the counter electrode), and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) (as the reference electrode). Differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) was performed from −0.4 V to 0.8 V with an amplitude of 0.05 V and increment of 0.004 V. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves were obtained in 5.0 mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− solution containing 0.1 M KCl. The parameters of EIS were as follows: the potential was 0.25 V, the frequency range was 100,000 Hz to 0.1 Hz and the amplitude of the applied sine wave was 0.05 V.

sections.heading: 2.3. The fabrication process of the aptasensor
sections.text:
Firstly, GCEs were polished with Al2O3 powder (diameter, 0.3 μm) and ultrasonically washed in Millipore water, absolute ethanol, and Millipore water for two minutes in sequence, respectively. Secondly, PANI was electrodeposited onto the pretreated electrodes in 1.0M HCl solution containing 0.1M aniline by cyclic voltammetry (CVs) (potential range: −0.2 V to 1.2 V; scan rates: 50mV s−1). The obtained electrode was defined as GCE/PANI. Thirdly, AuNPs were electrodeposited on the surface of GCE/PANI in 5.0mM HAuCl4 solution by chronoamperometry (potential: −0.3 V, time: 50 s), which was defined as GCE/PANI/Au. Fourthly, GCE/PANI/Au was immersed into peptide solution (0.4 mgmL−1) for 12 h to achieve the attachment of the peptides, which was defined as GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide. Then, GCE/PANI/ Au/Peptide was immersed into the solution containing 0.4 M EDC and 0.1M NHS to activate the carboxyl on peptide. The activated GCE/ PANI/Au/Peptide was incubated in 1.0 μMamino-functionalized aptamer solution for 2 h at 4℃ to acquire GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide/aptPSA. Finally, GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide/aptPSA was incubated in BSA solution (0.5 h, 4℃) to block any nonspecific binding sites. In addition, after each step, the modified electrode was washed by PBS (10mM, pH=7.4). The prepared aptasensor (GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide/aptPSA/
BSA) was stored at 4℃ before use.

sections.heading: 2.4. Antifouling performance investigation
sections.text: HSA (as single protein) and human serum (as complex protein) were chosen to assess the antifouling ability of the peptide-modified electrode. 1.0 ng mL−1 HSA solution was prepared by PBS (10mM, pH=7.4). Human serum samples were provided by Huangdao District Hospital of traditional Chinese Medicine (Qingdao, China) and diluted (V/V) to different concentrations (1%–40%) by PBS (10mM, pH=7.4). In this study, GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide and GCE/PANI/Au were incubated in HSA solution and human serum solutions with different concentrations for 30min, respectively. Then, DPV was used to detect the change of the current response before and after the above electrodes incubating in different protein solutions. According to that, the antifouling ability of the peptide-modified electrode would be investigated.

sections.heading: 3.1. Optimization of the conditions for PANI electrodeposition
sections.text:
To obtain better property of PANI-modified electrode, the deposition cycles were investigated. Based on the results shown in Fig. S1, it can be seen that the current response increased along with the increase of the deposition cycles from 5 cycles to 10 cycles, and then decreased beyond 10 cycles. So the optimized deposition cycles were 10 cycles. In order to explain the reasons for the above phenomena, the influence of different deposition cycles on the morphology was investigated, as can be seen in Fig. 1. When the deposition cycles were 5 cycles, the morphology of PANI was uneven, and the amount of deposited PANI was relatively small (Fig. 1A), which had less contact area with electrolyte. So the current response was relatively low. With increasing the deposition cycles to 10 cycles, a lot of coral-like PANI was electrodeposited on the electrode surface (Fig. 1B), which possessed large surface and provided more active sites for the growth of AuNPs. However, when the deposition cycles were increased to 15 cycles
(Fig. 1C), PANI was stacked on the GCE in the form of a block, and was unevenly distributed. Therefore, the optimal number of deposition cycles was 10.
3.2. Characterization of the modified electrode
The detailed morphologies of the formed PANI and PANI/Au were investigated by SEM, as can be seen in Fig. 2. At low magnification, PANI showed a three-dimensional coral structure, and there were a lot of holes on PANI (Fig. 2A). For the magnified image (Fig. 2B), the coral-like PANI was mainly composed of short rods (diameter was about 80 nm). Moreover, according to the RandleSevcik equation (ip = nFAC0.4463 ( ) nFvD RT
1/2) and the CV curve of Bare GCE and GCE/PANI (Fig. S2), it can be calculated that the effective surface area of Bare GCE and GCE/PANI was 56.6mm2 and 232mm2, respectively. Therefore, PANI with coral-like structure not only can enhance the current response by facilitating the charge transportation between the electrode and the active probe in electrolyte, but also could provide more active sites for growing AuNPs. The image of the coral-like PANI electrodeposited AuNPs is shown in Fig. 2C. As shown in Fig. 2C, bright AuNPs with the diameter of 50–80 nm were grown on coral-like PANI, which was beneficial for the attachment of the peptides on the electrode surface. And EDS spectra (Fig. 2D) of PANI/Au also demonstrated the existence of Au. Based on above results, it confirmed that PANI and AuNPs have been modified on electrode surface successfully.
To improve the antifouling ability, sensing surface with high hydrophilicity was introduced in this study. Hydrophilic surface has better antifouling performance because it can resist the nonspecific protein adsorption via hydration. For PSA aptasensor, the peptides (CRERERE) were introduced to enhance the antifouling ability. The hydrophilicity of ITO/PANI/Au and ITO/PANI/Au/Peptide was characterized by the static water contact angles, as shown in Table 1. In Table 1, the static water contact angle of bare ITO was 90.5°, and when PANI and Au were electrodeposited on ITO, it decreased to 48.5°. The results indicated that PANI and Au can improve the hydrophilicity of the modified surface to some extent. While the peptides were modified on ITO/PANI/
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of the PSA aptasensor.
Au, the contact angle decreased to 19.5°, indicating the excellent hydrophilicity of ITO/PANI/Au/Peptide. The reason of the increased hydrophilicity may be ascribed to the hydration between the amino and carboxyl group of the peptides and water molecule. The outstanding hydrophilicity of ITO/PANI/Au/Peptide would be beneficial to construct antifouling layer to reduce nonspecific adsorption, and furtherly improve the performance of the aptasensor.
3.3. Antifouling ability investigation of the peptide-modified electrode
To investigate the antifouling ability of the peptide-modified electrode surface, DPV was used to monitor the current response before and after GCE/PANI/Au and GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide incubating in HSA and human serum solutions, respectively. As can be seen in Fig. 3A, after GCE/PANI/Au incubating in HSA solution for 30min, the current response decreased significantly, and only remained 51.7% of the original value. The results indicated that HSA was severely adsorbed to GCE/ PANI/Au surface, hindering the charge transfer. While for GCE/PANI/ Au/Peptide (Fig. 3B), the current response had little decrease under the same experiments conditions (remained 87.5 of its initial value), indicating the antifouling ability of the electrode surface was improved. This result may because the peptides could reduce the HSA adsorption on the electrode surface. To further assess its antifouling ability in complex biological media, human serum solutions with different concentrations (V/V) were chosen. Fig. 3C shows the current response of GCE/PANI/Au incubated in the human serum solutions with different concentrations (from 1% to 20%). For GCE/PANI/Au, with increasing
the concentrations of serum solutions, its current response decreased significantly. And when the concentration of the serum solutions was 20%, the current response was only retained 29.1% of its original value. The results indicated that the proteins in human serum solution were strongly adsorbed to the electrode surface. However, for GCE/PANI/ Au/Peptide (Fig. 3D), when it was incubated in the serum solution with the concentration of 20%, the current response retained 96.8% of its initial value. When the concentration was up to 40%, the current response was still retained 88.2% of its initial value. The good hydrophilicity of the peptides can effectively reduce the nonspecific protein adsorption onto the electrode surface. So the proteins had a little impact on the current response. The above results indicated that GCE/PANI/ Au/Peptide had excellent antifouling ability, both in single and complex media.

sections.heading: 3.4. Fabrication process of the aptasensor
sections.text:
Based on the excellent antifouling ability of the peptide-modified electrode surface, an electrochemical aptasensor for detecting PSA was successfully fabricated. EIS was used to characterize the stepwise fabrication process of the aptasensor, and all EIS curves were fitted to a conventional Randles equivalent circuit, as can be seen in Fig. 4. After PANI was electrodeposited on bare GCE, the resistance (Rct) of GCE/ PANI apparently decreased, indicating PANI can enhance the electron transfer ability. The introduction of Au also caused the decrease of Rct, which was ascribed to the well conductivity and good dispersion of AuNPs. When the peptides were anchored on the electrode via Au-S bond, the Rct of GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide obviously increased. Because the non-conductive peptides can block the transfer of electrons between GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide surface and the active probe ([Fe(CN)6]3−/4−). Thus, it can be confirmed that the peptides were successfully attached on the electrode. After the aptPSA and BSA were subsequently immobilized on the modified-electrode (GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide/aptPSA/ BSA), the Rct was also increased, respectively. Therefore, according to the change of Rct, it can demonstrate that PANI, AuNPs, the peptides, aptPSA, and BSA had all been immobilized on the electrode, and PSA aptasensor was constructed successfully.
To furtherly verify the successful modification of the peptides and
the effective immobilization of aptPSA, XPS was used to analysis the elements change of PANI/Au, PANI/Au/Peptide, and PANI/Au/ Peptide/aptPSA, shown in Fig. 5. In Fig. 5A, the carbon (C1S, 285 eV), oxygen (O1S, 532 eV), and nitrogen (N1S, 400 eV) of PANI can be observed. Meanwhile, Au4f peaks located at 84 eV (Au 4f7/2) and 88 eV (Au 4f5/2) also appeared distinctly. Those all demonstrated that PANI and AuNPs were successfully electrodeposited on the electrode. After the peptides were anchored on the surface of PANI/Au (Fig. 5B), S2p emerged at 164 eV. Moreover, the peaks of N1S and O1S from amino and carboxyl of the peptides were enhanced as well. The above facts indicated that the peptides were successfully modified onto the surface of PANI/Au. For PANI/Au/Peptide/aptPSA (Fig. 5C), P2P at 135 eV as a characteristic peak of aptPSA was apparently observed, which was from the phosphate skeleton of the aptamer, indicating the effective immobilization of the aptamer. Additionally, O1s peak was also enhanced as can be seen in Fig. 5C, further indicating the successful
immobilization of aptPSA on PANI/Au/Peptide.

sections.heading: 3.5. Optimization of the detection conditions
sections.text: To obtain superior performance of the aptasensor, the influences of the incubation time, the temperature and pH of PBS on the detection performance were investigated. As can be seen in Fig. S3A, the change of current response (ΔI) increased with the increase of the incubation time, and the maximum of ΔI was obtained at 30min, indicating the appropriate incubation time was 30min. In Fig. S3B, as the incubation temperature continued to rise, ΔI gradually increased until the temperature was up to 37℃, and then it decreased when the temperature was 40℃. Hence, 37℃ would be chosen as the optimal incubation temperature. For the pH of PBS (Fig. S3C), the value of ΔI was increased from 6.0 to 7.4, while it decreased along with enlarging the value to 8.0. Obviously, pH 7.4 would be selected in the subsequent experiments. So the optimal incubation time was 30min, the optimal incubation temperature was 37℃, and the optimal pH of PBS was 7.4.

sections.heading: 3.6. Analytical performance of the aptasensor
sections.text:
Under the optimal experiment conditions, the analytical performance of the as-prepared aptasensor was monitored by DPV. In Fig. 6A, it shows that the current response of the aptasensor was gradually decreased along with the increase of PSA concentrations. Fig. 6B shows that the relationship of the current change (ΔI) and logarithm of PSA concentrations had a good linear range from 0.1 pg mL−1 to 100 ng mL−1. According to the equation (LOD=3Sb/m) [18], the limit of detection (LOD) was 0.085 pg mL−1 (S/N=3). Moreover, the sensitivity of the aptasensor was 462.7 μA(ng mL−1)−1 cm−2. The aptasensor with wide linear range, low LOD, and high sensitivity mainly attributed to the following aspects. On the one hand, coral-like PANI as the substrate materials had two benefits. Firstly, there were many holes in the three-dimensional structure of PANI, which can increase the contact area of the electrode with the electrolyte. Secondly, coral-like PANI contained many rod-like protruding sites, so it can provide more sites for the electrodeposition of AuNPs. Because of the special morphology of PANI and AuNPs, the analytical performance was
Fig. 3. Nonspecific adsorption measurements of GCE/PANI/Au and GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide in HSA and human serum solutions, respectively. (A, B) DPV response of GCE/PANI/Au and GCE/PANI/Au/Peptide before and after incubated in HSA solution. (C, D) DPV response of GCE/PANI/Au and GCE/PANI/Au/ Peptide before and after incubated in human serum solution with different concentrations.
Fig. 4. EIS curves of the different modified electrodes in 5.0 mM [Fe(CN)6]3−/ 4− solution containing 0.1M KCl.
significantly improved. On the other hand, the substrate materials were directly electrodeposited on the electrode, which can result in strong adhesion strength between the substrate materials and electrode, and then enhanced the electrons transfer. Moreover, electrodeposition method avoided the introduction of adhesive that can weaken performance. These factors also played a key role in improving the
performance of the aptasensor. In a word, the as-prepared aptasensor in this study exhibited excellent performance for detecting PSA compared with the reported works (Table 2).

sections.heading: 3.7. Selectivity, reproducibility and stability analysis of the aptasensor
sections.text:
In order to investigate the selectivity of the as-prepared aptasensor, CEA, IgG and HSA were introduced as the interfering substances. In the study of the selectivity, the concentrations of all interfering substances were 10 ng mL−1, while the concentration of PSA sample was 1.0 ng mL−1. As can be seen in Fig. S4A, for the interfering substances, the changes of the current response (ΔI) were all lower than 5 μA, indicating they had little effects on the current response of the aptasensor. Importantly, compared to the ΔI of pure PSA solution, it had no significant change when the aptasensor was incubated in the mixture of PSA, CEA, IgG, HSA. The results may because of the excellent antifouling ability of the aptasensor and the inherent affinity between the aptamer and PSA. All in all, the above analysis can indicate that the aptasensor possessed outstanding selectivity.
The reproducibility of an ideal aptasensor was also of vital importance for its practical application. To evaluate the reproducibility of the as-prepared aptasensor, five aptasensors were constructed under the same fabrication process for the detection of PSA (1.0 ng mL−1). As shown in Fig. S4B, the current responses of the five aptasensor were 250.4 μA, 252.6 μA, 251.2 μA, 254.3 μA and 250.8 μA, respectively, with the relative standard deviation (RSD) of 0.634%. The results confirmed that the aptasensor had admirable reproducibility.
The stability of the aptasensor was an important factor for the practical detection of PSA. The five prepared aptasensors were stored in 4℃ for 7 days, respectively. Then the aptasensors were used to detect 1.0 ng mL−1 PSA to measure its stability. The current response of them changed about 3%–10% of the initial value (Fig. S4C), indicating that the aptasensor had a satisfying stability for PSA detection.

sections.heading: 3.8. Application of the aptasensor
sections.text: To investigate the feasibility of the aptasensor for potential applications, the recovery experiments were implemented to detect PSA in 10% human serum solutions according to the standard addition method. In the experiment, PSA was separately doped in 10% human serum solutions to get the samples with the concentration of 0.100 ng mL−1, 1.00 ng mL−1 and 10.0 ng mL−1. As shown in Table 3, the recovery of the samples was 106.1%, 104.8% and 99.43%, and the RSD of them was 3.12%, 2.68% and 3.34%, respectively. The results powerfully demonstrated that the prepared aptasensor had potential application in clinical analysis.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, an aptasensor with excellent detection performance and antifouling ability for PSA detection was constructed. Coral-like PANI and AuNPs were prepared by electrodeposition method, which played a key role in improving the detection performance of the aptasensor. The as-prepared aptasensor exhibited a wide linear range (0.1 pg mL−1 to 100 ng mL−1), a low LOD (0.085 pg mL−1) and a high sensitivity (462.7 μA(ng mL−1)−1 cm−2). Moreover, it also has outstanding selectivity, admirable reproducibility and satisfying stability. The outstanding detection and antifouling performances were mainly due to the substrate materials with special morphologies, the introduction of the peptides and the enhanced the binding force between the substrate materials and the electrode. What’s more, the as-prepared aptasensor showed potential application in clinical analysis.
Conflicts of interest
There are no conflicts to declare.

sections.text: The work reported here was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant Nos. 51672144, 51572137, 51502149, 51702181, the Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province under Grant No. ZR2016EMB25, ZR2017PEM006, ZR2017BB013, the Higher Educational Science and Technology Program of Shandong Province under Grant No.J16LA10, J17KA014, the Application Foundation Research Program of Qingdao under Grant No. 15-9-1-28-jch, the Taishan Scholars Program of Shandong Province under No. ts201511034 and the Overseas Taishan Scholars Program. sections.text: Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.snb.2019.05.070.

Nowadays, the peptides are attracting more and more attention because of their simple synthetic process and low cost [24].
In addition, the peptides have alternating carboxyl (−COOH) and amino groups (-NH2), which can strongly bind to water molecules via hydration to improve the hydrophilicity of the surface [25].

metadata.abstractText: Prostate specific antigen (PSA), as the significant biomarker of prostate cancer, has aroused widespread concern. However, constructing the PSA aptasensor with high sensitivity and low detection limit is still facing huge challenges. In this study, a sensitive electrochemical aptasensor for detecting PSA based on coral-like polyaniline (PANI)/gold nano-particles (AuNPs) and the peptides was constructed. Coral-like PANI and AuNPs with the diameter of 50–80 nm, as the substrate materials, were directly deposited on glass carbon electrode (GCE) by electrodeposited method. Then, the peptides, as the antifouling materials, were anchored on the modifiedelectrode, which not only can form antifouling surface to reduce nonspecific adsorption, but also can be as a medium between the modified-electrode and PSA aptamer. Finally, the PSA aptamer was immobilized on the electrode. Based on the synergistic effect of excellent conductivity and special morphology of the substrate materials, and the antifouling ability of peptides, the aptasensor exhibited a high sensitivity of 462.7 μA(ng mL) cm, wide linear range from 0.1 pg mL to 100 ng mL, low limit of detection (LOD) of 0.085 pg mL and good antifouling performance. The aptasensor also possessed outstanding selectivity, reproducibility and stability. Moreover, the aptasensor can directly detect PSA in 10% human serum solutions.
